instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: MacBook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B fans spin at max RPM
threads.message:
MacBook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B fans spin at max RPM as soon as the MacBook is turned on, no water damage either, MacBook functions totally fine but with fans at max RPM.

The weird part is that when we got the MacBook the problem was not there, after a few restarts its back, temperature reading from all sensors are fine.

ASD reports error with: Motor unable to stabilize between min and max limits, attachment shows full report.

threads.title: MacBook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B fans spin at max RPM
threads.message:
Did you try another fan?
Check around J6000, <TRANSISTOR>Q6060</TRANSISTOR>, <CHIP>U6010</CHIP>.

threads.title: MacBook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B fans spin at max RPM
threads.message: Yes 2 new fans and same thing, J6000, <TRANSISTOR>Q6060</TRANSISTOR>, <CHIP>U6010</CHIP> all look clean, after I tried a new IO board and flex it worked fine, but I put the old IO and flex back on and it is also working fine. I will leave it alone now that it works and hope it won't come back.

threads.title: MacBook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B fans spin at max RPM
threads.message: You probably had bad contacts on LIO connector...
